site_name: 7 Knights Park,Kingston Upon Thames,KT1 2QH
description: Erection of a part single storey part two storey side and rear extension with 3 x roof lights
decision_conditions: The development hereby permitted shall begin before the expiration of three years from the date of this permission.Reason:  As required  by Section 91 of  the Town  and Country Planning  Act  1990,  as amended by Section 51 of the Planning and Compulsory Purchase Act 2004.

Notwithstanding the information provided on the approved drawings, details of the facing materials to be utilised in the development hereby permitted shall have been submitted to and approved in writing by the Local Planning Authority before any above ground works on site are commenced. The development shall then be built in accordance with these approved samples.Reason: It is necessary to provide these details prior to commencement as it is integral to the design and appearance of the building and to ensure a satisfactory appearance on completion of the development in accordance with Policy DM10 (Design Requirements for New Developments including House Extensions) of the LDF Core Strategy Adopted April 2012.

Notwithstanding the details shown on the approved drawings the development hereby approved shall not be occupied until a detailed planting plan for the sedum roof has been submitted and approved in writing by the Local Planning Authority. The approved scheme shall be implemented within the first planting season following completion of the development and shall therefore after be maintained for five years to the satisfaction of the Local Planning Authority. Any shrubs which die during this period shall be replaced in the first available planting season. Reason: In the interests of visual amenity and also that the Local Planning Authority shall be satisfied as to the details of the development in accordance with Policy DM10 (Design Requirements for New Developments including House Extensions) of the LDF Core Strategy Adopted April 2012.

Notwithstanding the details shown on the approved drawings the development hereby approved shall not be occupied until boundary treatment details along the shared boundary with number 5 Knights Park has been submitted and approved in writing by the Local Planning Authority. The approved details shall have been carried out prior to the occupation of the development. Reason: In order to ensure the privacy and visual amenity of adjoining occupiers is retained in accordance with Policy DM10 (Design Requirements for New Developments including House Extensions) of the LDF Core Strategy Adopted April 2012.

The roof of the ground floor extensions hereby permitted shall not be converted or used as a balcony or a sitting out area, and no access shall be gained except for maintenance purposes.Reason: To protect the amenities and privacy of the adjoining residential properties in accordance with Policy DM10 (Design Requirements for New Developments including House Extensions) of the LDF Core Strategy Adopted April 2012.

In dealing with the application the Council has implemented the requirement in the National Planning Policy Framework to work with the applicant in a positive and proactive way.  We have made available detailed advice in the form or our statutory policies in the Core Strategy, Supplementary Planning Documents, Planning Briefs and other informal written guidance, as well as offering a full pre-application advice service, in order to ensure that the applicant has been given every opportunity to submit an application which is likely to be considered favourably.

Application SiteThe site comprises a semi-detached, two-storey dwelling located to the northern side of Tudor Drive. The site is not subject to any particular designations or environmental constraints.ProposalThe application seeks planning permission for the erection of two storey side and single storey rear extension, hip to gable roof extension with rear dormer and installation of 4 nos front rooflights to facilitate loft conversion.Consultation18 properties were notified of the proposal. No representations were received.No statutory or internal consultations necessary.AssessmentThe main issues in the assessment of the application are:- The impact on the character and appearance of the area; and- The impact on the amenities of neighbouring occupiers.Character and AppearancePolicy D3 of the London Plan 2021 states that development proposals should enhance local context by delivering buildings and spaces that positively respond to local distinctiveness through their layout, orientation, scale, appearance and shape, with due regard to existing and emerging street hierarchy, building types, forms and proportions.Policies CS8 and DM10 of the Council's Core Strategy 2012 and the guidance in the Council's Residential Design Guide SPD 2013 require proposals to be of a high quality design that respects the character and appearance of the original building and the prevailing character of the surrounding area.Policy Guidance 33 (Single-Storey Rear Extensions), Policy Guidance 36 (Two-storey Side and First Floor Side Extensions) Policy Guidance 39 (Roof Dormers) and Section 4.29 relating to gable end extensions of the SPD Guidance are applicable to this application.Single-Storey Rear ExtensionThe SPD guidance advises that single storey rear extensions should be designed so that they appear proportionate and subordinate to the host building. The proposed extension would conflict with the guidelines set out in the Residential Design SPD, 2013 with regards to depth. Officers note that although the neighbouring property at No.155 Tudor Drive has not been extended to the rear, other rear extensions of a similar depth are evident in the vicinity of the application property.The extension would be full width and stepped with two pitched roof elements that would maintain a similar depth to the existing rear extension one side and project beyond this point as it relates to the shared boundary with No.155 Tudor Drive. A timber clad lean-to structure would be located on the shared boundary with No.151 Tudor Drive.Although officers consider a reduction in depth to be more acceptable, the proposed extension would not be visible from the street scene, and the property is not located within a Conservation Area and therefore the impact on the surrounding area would not be significant. no adverse impacts on the character or appearance of the area.Hip to Gable Roof Extension:According to section 4.29 of the Residential Design SPD, this type of hip-to-gable roof extension are not usually appropriate as they are often at odds with the existing character of a property. This may be particularly true when proposing to extend the roof of a semi-detached property, which would upset the visual balance of the two houses, particularly when viewed in the context of other houses in the street or wider area. In this instance, the proposed hip to gable roof extension would alter the symmetry of this pair of semi-detached dwellinghouses.  Notwithstanding, Officers note that there are a variety of roof forms evident along Tudor Drive and there are examples, including some nearby to the application site, where one half of a semi-detached dwelling pair have altered the roof form from hip to gable end. It is therefore considered on balance that the proposed hip to gable roof extension would not appear unduly different within, or be harmful to, the character and appearance of the application property, adjoining property or wider streetscene. Rear Roof Dormer:Policy Guidance 39 of the Residential Design SPD states that dormer windows should be designed so that they: -	are set down from the ridge line of the existing roof by at least 500mm; -	are set in from the sides and eaves of the roof by at least 500mm; -	do not feature on the front slope of the roof (in most cases); -	are designed to complement the character of the existing house and wider area; match or line-up with any original windows below; and-	are not built in the style of a mansard roof The proposed rear dormer would be sited below the ridgeline however does not appear to be set down or set in from the side and eaves of the roof in accordance with the SPD. Officers do note other large rear dormers in the vicinity of the application property and that the proposed rear dormer roof extensions, with some minor amendments, would fall within the parameters of permitted development. Although possibly an error officers note the proposed elevations show the rear dormer to extend beyond the application property, which would also indicate the rear dormer to be of an inappropriate scale. It is therefore considered that the proposed rear dormer would be incompatible and excessive in scale to the detriment of the host dwelling in terms of materiality and appearance and would not be a subordinate addition at roof level. The proposed rooflights to the front roof slope are considered to be of a size and design appropriate to the host dwellinghouse and would not appear unduly uncharacteristic in the streetscene. Two  Storey Side Extension:The proposed side extension would be setback from the front elevation in accordance with the SPD, and would incorporate a roof profile that reflects and relates well to the main house and its roof form, however would be located on the shared boundary which could encourage a terrace effect should a similar development take place at the neighbouring property. It is also noted the separation between dwellings along Tudor Drive is fairly uniform and consistent. A reduction in scale or setback of the proposed extension would be necessary to preserve the character and appearance of the streetscene and to appear proportionate and subordinate to the host dwelling.  Overall, it is considered that the proposed development would detract from the character and appearance of the host property, and the surrounding area and therefore would accord with Policies CS8 and DM10 of the Council's adopted LFD Core Strategy April 2012.Neighbouring AmenitiesPolicy D3 of the London Plan 2021 states that development proposals should deliver appropriate outlook, privacy and amenity, and should help prevent or mitigate the impacts of noise and poor air quality.Policy DM10 of the Council's Core Strategy also seeks to safeguard the amenities of neighbouring occupiers. To this end, it states that developments should have regard to the amenities of occupants and neighbours, including in terms of privacy, outlook, sunlight/daylight, avoidance of visual intrusion and noise and disturbance.In terms of neighbouring residential amenity, the main properties to consider are No.s 151 and 155 Tudor Drive. The property at No.155 Tudor Drive has not been extended to the  rear and the proposed rear extension would extend beyond this building line and the parameters of the SPD in terms of depth. There are habitable windows to the rear of No.151 which would experience some loss of outlook. It has not been demonstrated that the proposed extension would accord with the BRE 45-degree rule to ensure there is no undie loss of daylight/sunlight to this property.In relation to No.151, the proposed two storey extension would be located along the shared boundary. Although there would be some separation between the proposed extension and the dwelling at No.151 this is afforded only due to the absence of a side extension at No.151. There are windows proposed to the side elevation of the extension and windows to the facing elevation of No.s15 which would be affected by loss of outlook, an undue sense of enclosure and loss of daylight/sunlight, although officers note it has not been demonstrated how the proposed extension would accord with the BRE guidance in relation to these windows. The combined scale and design of the proposed extension is considered to unduly impact the amenities of both neighbouring properties and cause significant harm to the outlook, privacy and daylight/sunlight provision of the neighbouring occupiers. ConclusionIn conclusion, the proposed development would not be in general accordance with the National Planning Policy Framework (2021), the National Planning Practice Guidance, the London Plan (2021), Policies of the Core Strategy (2012) and the Residential Design SPD (2013).

Application SiteThe site comprises of a Neo-Georgian, detached two-storey dwelling located to the eastern side of Upper Brighton Road, Surbiton.The site does not comprise of a listed building, however the site is located within the Southborough Conservation Area. ProposalThe application seeks planning permission for the erection of single-storey rear extension. Conversion of existing garage into habitable space. Replacement of existing glass roof with raised pitched tiled roof. Replacement of front canopy to entrance. Associated changes to fenestration. Raising height of the front boundary wall with installation of electric gates.Consultation23no. properties were notified of the proposal. One representation received raising comments regarding potential for overlooking / loss of privacy to rear patio of neighbouring dwelling.Surbiton Conservation Area Advisory Committee (CAAC): No objection.RBK Neighbourhood Traffic Engineer: No comments.RBK Tree and Landscape Officer: No comments.AssessmentThe main issues in the assessment of the application are:- The impact on the character and appearance of the area; - The impact upon heritage assets; - The impact on the amenities of neighbouring occupiers; and - Highways and TransportationCharacter and AppearancePolicy D3 of the London Plan 2021 states that development proposals should enhance local context by delivering buildings and spaces that positively respond to local distinctiveness through their layout, orientation, scale, appearance and shape, with due regard to existing and emerging street hierarchy, building types, forms and proportions.Policies CS8 and DM10 of the Council's Core Strategy 2012 and the guidance in the Council's Residential Design Guide SPD 2013 require proposals to be of a high quality design that respects the character and appearance of the original building and the prevailing character of the surrounding area.The single-storey rear infill extension would not comply with the guidance set out Policy 33 of the Residential Design SPD (in terms of depth) but this is considered acceptable in this instance given it would effectively infill a gap to the rear elevation and be set back from the existing rear projecting addition by 1.4m. The proposals include a partial infill at first floor level to marginally increase the size of the bathroom and replace the existing glass wall with two separate matching windows. This is considered to be a positive improvement to the dwellinghouse, complementary to its appearance and materiality. The first floor rear facing window would be altered to reduce its length but would be fitted with replacement stained glass. Whilst it is regrettable that the feature window would be altered and no longer full length, Officers welcome the intention to utilise stained glass in the resized window, as annotated on the plans. The proposed conversion of the integral garage to habitable room, with the associated removal of the garage door and replacement with a window to the front elevation is considered to be acceptable in terms of design and appearance, with matching windows and brickwork used to present a consistent fa√ßade to the principal elevation.The application also proposes the demolition of the existing lean-to structure to the side of the dwelling. Officers consider this to be an improvement, providing independent means of side access to the rear garden and visual separation between the application property and the neighbouring dwelling at No. 19B Upper Brighton Road. The scale of the proposed front canopy is subservient to the front elevation and similar in scale to that evident at No.19b Upper Brighton Road. There is an existing smaller canopy with a triangular pitched roof and the same design is proposed. The increased depth of the existing canopy from 0.25m to 1m will not affect the parking or turning cycle of vehicles on the driveway.The proposed front wall would measure to a height of 1.3m. The proposed wall and gate to the front curtilage follows the same design principle as the existing wall and is similar to others found along the Upper Brighton Road (e.g. No. 14, No. 14a, No. 25, No. 25A), therefore the proposed height and design would not be out of character as set out in Policy Guidance 44 of the Council's Residential Design SPD. The gates will be sliding behind the walls in accordance with the guidance and this design thus ensures no loss of parking nor interference with the highway.The current front boundary is marked by a brick wall so there will be no loss of hedgerows and the existing foundations will be reused to avoid disturbing the existing trees behind.Overall, it is not considered the proposed development would detract from the character and appearance of the host property, as well as the surrounding area and therefore would accord with Policies CS8 and DM10 of the Council's adopted LFD Core Strategy April 2012.Impact upon Heritage AssetsSections 16 and 66 of the Planning (Listed Buildings and Conservation Areas) Act 1990 (as amended) state that in considering whether to grant planning permission for development which affects a listed building or its setting, the local planning authority shall have special regard to the desirability of preserving the building or its setting or any features of special architectural or historic interest which it possesses.Section 72 of the Planning (Listed Buildings and Conservation Areas) Act 1990 (as amended) places a duty on local planning authorities to pay special attention to the desirability of preserving or enhancing the character and appearance of conservation areas, when considering development proposals that would affect land or buildings within them.Paragraphs 199 to 208 of the NPPF 2021 set out the method for assessing the impact of development proposals on heritage assets. Policy HC1 of the London Plan 2021 and Policies CS8 and DM12 of the Council's Core Strategy 2012 echo these requirements.When considering the impact of a proposed development on the significance of a designated heritage asset, great weight should be given to the asset's conservation (and the more important the asset, the greater the weight should be). This is irrespective of whether any potential harm amounts to substantial harm, total loss or less than substantial harm to its significance.The proposed extension would change the appearance of the building. However, it is considered that the proposed rear extension would not constitute a harmful addition to detrimentally affect the character of the host building and it is considered that the extension would not result in harm to the setting of the Conservation Area given its scale and design, and the fact it would be set behind the existing massing of the application property. The other elements of the application proposals including the fenestration changes and alterations to the porch, garage and side infill extension are all considered to be appropriate to the setting of the Conservation Area and would not constitute harmful alterations to the overall character and appearance of the dwelling or wider area.It is considered that the proposals would not result in any harm to the significance of the conservation area. As such, the proposed development would accord with Section 72 of the Planning Listed Building and Conservation Areas Act 1990, paragraphs 197 - 206 of the NPPF, policy HC1 of the London Plan 2021 and policies CS8, DM10 and DM12 of the Council's adopted LDF Core Strategy April 2012.Neighbouring AmenitiesPolicy D3 of the London Plan 2021 states that development proposals should deliver appropriate outlook, privacy and amenity, and should help prevent or mitigate the impacts of noise and poor air quality.Policy DM10 of the Royal Borough of Kingston upon Thames Local Development Framework Core Strategy (CS) (2012) and the guidance in the Royal Borough of Kingston upon Thames Residential Design SPD (2013) requires proposal to have regard to the amenities of the future occupants of the development as well as those of the existing occupants of neighbouring land and buildings, including in terms of privacy, outlook, sunlight/daylight, avoidance of visual intrusion and noise and disturbance.The proposed single-storey rear extension includes one side-facing window. However, the application is supported by site photographs and Officers consider that given the boundary treatment in place along this shared boundary, the presence of the single-storey side structure with pitched roof belonging to No. 19B closest to side boundary, as well as the proposed positioning of the side window nearest to this structure, that the window would not result in any loss of privacy or opportunity for overlooking towards No. 19B. The proposed extension would not impact upon No. 19 in respect of sense of enclosure, loss of privacy or overlooking.The proposed alterations at first floor level would simply replicate the existing scenario. Upon officers request, the applicant has submitted revised plan (dwg no. 885-A-114_P2) with annotations to specify that the windows at first floor to the flank wall of the rear extension would be fitted with obscure-glazing. As such, Officers are satisfied that the proposals would not adversely impact upon the amenities of the neighbouring property or garden at No. 19B and further southwards, beyond. The other alterations proposed as part of this planning application would not result in undue impact on the amenity of either neighbouring property in terms of visual intrusion, loss of daylight, sunlight or privacy.It is considered that the proposed development by virtue of its size, siting and design in relation to the neighbouring properties would not cause significant harm to the outlook, privacy and daylight/sunlight provision of the neighbouring occupiers and would therefore comply with Policy D3 of the London Plan 2021 and Policy DM10 of the Council's adopted LDF Core Strategy April 2012.Highways and TransportationUpon officer's request, the front boundary wall treatment was revised to include a low brick wall (1m in height) with railing atop. Vehicular access via sliding electronically-operated gates, solid to 1m with open grill atop to correspond with wall and railings.Following review from RBK Highways Officers, they have not raised any concerns regarding visibility and highway safety from the boundary treatment, as revised (plan ref: 885-A-115_P2). Overall, the proposed development is considered to be acceptable in terms of highway safety and as such would accord with Policies DM9 and DM10 of the LDF Core Strategy 2012.ConclusionThe proposal accords with the principles contained with policies CS8 and DM10 of the Core Strategy and Policy D3 of the London Plan 2021 in that it would relate well to the design of the existing dwellinghouse and would have no adverse impact on the character or quality of the character of the streetscene. The proposed development would have an acceptable impact on the character and appearance of the wider conservation area, in accordance with policy DM12 of the Core Strategy and policy HC1 of the London Plan 2021.In terms of neighbouring amenity, it is not considered to result in any undue harm in regards to overlooking, loss of privacy, daylight or outlook provision. The scheme is therefore considered to be acceptable and in accordance with the LDF Core Strategy Core Policies. Officers conclude that planning permission should be granted.
The proposed pergola would be would be situated on land forward of a wall forming the principal elevation of the original dwellinghouse.
The proposed pergola would measure over 2.5 metres in height in the case of an enclosure within 2 metres of the boundary of the curtilage of the dwellinghouse.

Please note that the Certificate B Notice will need to be served on the Highways Department. Whilst the application is to the council, even though the land is owned by Highways, notice still needs to be served in this regard, as per planning regulations
Submitted drawing Existing Elevations and 3ds has no drawing number displayed. Please correct and resubmit this drawing
Please be advised that the plan 1056-16A Proposed Elevations  does not show the full extent of the elevational proposal. Kindly provide the full plan and resubmit

We received an email regarding another application for 10 new additional dwellings, if another application has not been decided and has not been constructed and completed on the proposed site, this application will consider as fourth and fifth floor extension with 10 new dwellings. The submitted drawings shows 10 new dwellings. If you do not want to include the new dwellings in this application, please amend the documents accordingly.

Please note that we have only received plans marked as Existing - and these existing plans show 7 existing bedrooms, and not that of a dwellinghouse as Existing. Kindly provide existing and proposed floor plans and elevations, and ensure all floor plans show a north point
